newsitem.title: UK: Sales triple at Britain's biggest air show.
newsitem.headline: Sales triple at Britain's biggest air show.

text.p: Sales have already more than tripled at Britain's biggest ever air show, giving a welcome boost to a world aerospace industry emerging from the storm clouds of recession.

Passenger jet rivals Boeing and Airbus Industrie alone have announced orders priced at more than $9 billion in the first three days of the show and industry sources said on Wednesday that more were in the pipeline.
This was in sharp contrast to the $3 billion total announced by all companies at the last Farnborough show in 1994.
Boeing and Airbus bickered over which had the biggest market share and argued over the value of producing a new "superjumbo" to cope with rising demand. But both agreed business was booming.

"Traffic is up and airline profits are up. Our customers have emerged from some very difficult years in the first part of this decade with renewed strength and determination," said Boeing Commercial Airplane Group President Ron Woodard.
Airbus' chief operating officer Volker von Tein echoed his optimism.
"A number of airlines, after many years of deficit are trading at a profit...Many of them have started to address their reflecting needs in earnest," he said at the international aviation showcase.
But with development costs soaring and competition intensifying, the message from industry leaders in both civil aviation and defence was the same -- mergers are vital to survival.
"The projects of tomorrow are going to be very, very expensive," Britain's deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine told the 1,000 exhibitors from 60 nations when opening the week-long show on Monday.
U.S. manufacturers have bitten the bullet with a string of mega mergers. Europe will have to follow suit to compete.
Britain gave a welcome boost to the Eurofighter, a joint venture with Germany, Italy and Spain that had been dogged by years of political wrangling, cost overruns and technical problems.
It gave the production go-ahead for 232 of the 21st century combat jets. The plane was then put through its paces over the skies of Farnborough before the world's most influential buyers.
The members of the four-nation Airbus Industrie consortium are pressing ahead with plans to merge their civil aircraft production plants into one company.
But there are also aspirations within the group to take over and consolidate Europe's defence industry.
"Potentially this is going to be the biggest industrial company in Europe," said Sir Richard Evans, chief executive of Airbus partner British Aerospace Plc.

The Airbus consortium said it is pressing ahead with plans to build the world's biggest passenger jet despite dire warnings from Boeing that the "superjumbo" market was not big enough for both of them.
Boeing, weighing a $5 billion plan to build a stretch version of its veteran 747 jumbo jet, said Airbus would be committing financial suicide with its $8 billion project to build the 550-seat A3XX.
"It is hard to imagine that Airbus can do a totally new airplane for an $8 billion investment," said Boeing's Woodard, who launched into a dogfight with Airbus over the future of the market.
But the new kid on the block was unrepentant with Airbus' von Tein defiantly responding: "Our A3XX will begin its life where the B747 ends."
